description: From Middle English rail, rayl, *reȝel, *reȝol (found in reȝolsticke (“a ruler”)), partly from Old English regol (“a ruler, straight bar”) and partly from Old French reille; both from Latin regula (“rule, bar”), from regō (“to rule, to guide, to govern”); see regular.

entries.meaning: A horizontal bar extending between supports and used for support or as a barrier; a railing.
The metal bar forming part of the track for a railroad.
A railroad; a railway, as a means of transportation.
examples: We travelled to the seaside by rail.
a small Scottish village not accessible by rail

entries.meaning: (electronics) A conductor maintained at a fixed electrical potential relative to ground, to which other circuit components are connected.
examples: ISA devices draw power from the +5 V, −5 V, +12 V, and −12 V rails of the power supply unit.

entries.meaning: A horizontal piece of wood that serves to separate sections of a door or window.
(surfing) One of the lengthwise edges of a surfboard.
examples: Rails alone can only ever have a marginal effect on a board's general turning ability.

entries.meaning: (Internet) A vertical section on one side of a web page.
examples: We're experimenting with ads in the right-hand rail.

entries.meaning: (drugs) A large line (portion or serving of a powdery illegal drug).
examples: Do a couple rails and chase your own tail

verbs.description: rail (third-person singular simple present rails, present participle railing, simple past and past participle railed)

examples: Mottram of the Indian Survey had ridden thirty and railed one hundred miles from his lonely post in the desert  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive, rail transport, of rolling stock) To place on a track.
(transitive) To enclose with rails or a railing.
examples: It ought to be fenced in and railed.
They were brought to London all railed in ropes, like a team of horses in a cart.

entries.meaning: (transitive, vulgar, slang) To sexually penetrate in a rough manner.

description: From French râle, rale, from Middle French raalle, from Old French rasle. Compare Medieval Latin rallus. Named from its harsh cry, Vulgar Latin *rasculum, from Latin rādere (“to scrape”).

entries.meaning: Any of several birds in the family Rallidae.

verbs.description: rail (third-person singular simple present rails, present participle railing, simple past and past participle railed)

description: From Middle English rail, reil, from Old English hræġl (“garment, dress, robe”). Cognate with Old Frisian hreil, reil, Old Saxon hregil, Old High German hregil (“clothing, garment, dress”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An item of clothing; a cloak or other garment; a dress.
(obsolete) Specifically, a woman's headscarf or neckerchief.

description: Probably from Anglo-Norman raier, Middle French raier.

verbs.description: rail (third-person singular simple present rails, present participle railing, simple past and past participle railed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, of a liquid) To gush; to flow.
